titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the William Somerset Maugham collection, 1921-1979 (inclusive), 1921-1958 (bulk) M0013

publicationstmt.publisher: Department of Special Collections and University Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2009-08-04T09:52-0700
profiledesc.langusage: Finding aid is written in English.

repository.corpname: Department of Special Collections and University Archives

odd.head: General note
odd.p: All letters are from W. Somerset Maugham to Bertram Alanson in San Francisco unless otherwise noted.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Boxes 1,2,2b 3: copy of The Trembling of a Leaf

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Bertram E. Alanson was born January 8, 1877 in San Francisco, California. He was an investment broker and served as President of the San Francisco Stock Exchange. Alanson was a personal friend of Maugham as well as his stockbroker. He collected first editions of Maugham's work and other materials about Maugham. Alanson died May 25, 1958.

William Somerset Maugham was born in Paris, France January 25, 1874. He studied medicine, but gave it up for literature. He wrote short stories, essays, and novels. He died in Nice, France December 15, 1965.

scopecontent.head: Scope Note
scopecontent.p: This collection consists mainly of W. Somerset Maugham's correspondence with Bertram Alanson, dating from 1921 through 1958 when Alanson died. Alanson was Maugham's investment consultant, but more importantly he was Maugham's friend. The letters are very revealing about Maugham's activities, his philosophy, his works.
There is additional correspondence to Alanson; some concerning Maugham and some are written by members of Maugham's family.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation:
prefercite.p: [Identification of item] William Somerset Maugham collection, M0013, Dept. of Special Collections, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

custodhist.head: Provenance:
custodhist.p: Gift of Bertram E. Alanson, 1957 and 1958.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights:
userestrict.p: Property rights reside with the repository. Literary rights reside with the creators of the documents or their heirs. To obtain permission to publish or reproduce, please contact the Public Services Librarian of the Dept. of Special Collections.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: “I cannot imagine that my letters to Bertram Alanson could be of any interest to anyone else, and the idea that they might be useful to scholars makes me laugh...I am resigned to being completely forgotten five years after my death.”

scopecontent.p: Health, Willie had fallen and injured himself, Royal Academy dinner.

scopecontent.p: Willie's medical check-up, “Stanford to get the manuscript of the Ten Novelists' and I shall let them have my collection of Maughamiana. All the first editions, a lot of letters addressed to Willie by eminent people, photographs, “etc.”.

scopecontent.p: Thank you letter for a tie, working as a judge's marshall, Bar exams, reaction to Germany's treatment of Jews.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Prime Minister's return from Munich, hysteria in England, approaching war, Willie has put on weight, England in winter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Editing a paper “which I hope will do something to help the War Effort, Xmas and “happier” New Year which will see the final defeat of the Japanese and the Germans. Envelope bears Censor's label.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Grateful to Willie, learning about business.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His film The Intruder opened in Edinburgh to good reviews.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
